examples.title: Subgroup Criterion
examples.statement: Show that H = {1, -1, i, -i} is a subgroup of (ℂ×, ·).

steps.title: Check non-empty
steps.content: H contains 1 (the identity of ℂ×).

steps.title: Check closure
steps.content:
Verify products: 1·x = x, (-1)(-1) = 1, (-1)(i) = -i, (-1)(-i) = i, i·i = -1, i·(-i) = 1, (-i)(-i) = -1.
All products are in H.

steps.title: Check inverses
steps.content:
1⁻¹ = 1, (-1)⁻¹ = -1, i⁻¹ = -i, (-i)⁻¹ = i.
All inverses are in H.

solution.conclusion: H is a subgroup of ℂ×. In fact, H is the cyclic group generated by i, so H ≅ ℤ₄.

examples.title: The One-Step Subgroup Test
examples.statement: State and apply the one-step subgroup test to show that the set of even integers is a subgroup of (ℤ, +).

steps.title: State the test
steps.content: A nonempty subset H of a group G is a subgroup if and only if ab⁻¹ ∈ H for all a, b ∈ H.

steps.title: Apply to 2ℤ
steps.content:
Let H = 2ℤ = {..., -4, -2, 0, 2, 4, ...}.
H is nonempty (contains 0).
For any a = 2m, b = 2n ∈ H:
a - b = 2m - 2n = 2(m - n) ∈ H.

solution.conclusion: By the one-step subgroup test, 2ℤ is a subgroup of ℤ.

steps.title: Part (a)
steps.content:
nℤ = {nk : k ∈ ℤ}.
0 = n·0 ∈ nℤ (identity).
nk + nm = n(k+m) ∈ nℤ (closure).
-(nk) = n(-k) ∈ nℤ (inverses).
Thus nℤ ≤ ℤ.

steps.title: Part (b)
steps.content:
⟨4̄⟩ = {0̄, 4̄, 8̄, 12̄, 16̄}.
This is the cyclic subgroup generated by 4̄, hence a subgroup.

steps.title: Part (c)
steps.content:
H = {1, (1 2 3), (1 3 2)} contains the identity.
(1 2 3)(1 2 3) = (1 3 2) ∈ H.
(1 2 3)(1 3 2) = 1 ∈ H.
(1 3 2)(1 3 2) = (1 2 3) ∈ H.
(1 2 3)⁻¹ = (1 3 2) ∈ H.
Thus H is closed and closed under inverses.

steps.title: Part (d)
steps.content:
Check closure: r²·r² = r⁴ = 1, s·s = 1, s·r² = sr², r²·s = sr⁻² = sr², sr²·sr² = s(r²s)r² = s(sr⁻²)r² = s²r⁻²⁺² = 1.
Inverses: (r²)⁻¹ = r², s⁻¹ = s, (sr²)⁻¹ = r⁻²s⁻¹ = r²s = sr⁻² = sr².
All conditions satisfied.

steps.title: Part (e)
steps.content:
H = SL₂(ℝ). det(I) = 1, so I ∈ H.
If det(A) = det(B) = 1, then det(AB) = det(A)det(B) = 1.
det(A⁻¹) = 1/det(A) = 1.
Thus H ≤ GL₂(ℝ).

solution.conclusion: All five subsets are subgroups of their respective groups.

steps.title: Part (a): Non-negative integers
steps.content:
ℤ≥0 is not closed under inverses.
1 ∈ ℤ≥0 but 1⁻¹ = -1 ∉ ℤ≥0.
Alternatively: 2 - 3 = -1 ∉ ℤ≥0 (not closed under subtraction).

steps.title: Part (b): Odd integers
steps.content:
The odd integers don't contain the identity 0.
Also, 1 + 3 = 4 is not odd (not closed under addition).

solution.conclusion: (a) fails closure under inverses; (b) fails to contain identity and fails closure.

exercises.statement: Let G be an abelian group. Prove that {g ∈ G | |g| < ∞} is a subgroup of G (called the torsion subgroup of G).

steps.title: Let T = {g ∈ G | |g| < ∞}
steps.content: We need to show T is a subgroup.

steps.title: Closure
steps.content:
Let a, b ∈ T with |a| = m and |b| = n.
Since G is abelian: (ab)^{mn} = a^{mn}b^{mn} = (a^m)^n(b^n)^m = 1^n · 1^m = 1.
Thus |ab| divides mn, so |ab| < ∞, hence ab ∈ T.

steps.title: Inverses
steps.content:
If |a| = n, then (a⁻¹)^n = (a^n)⁻¹ = 1⁻¹ = 1.
So |a⁻¹| divides n, hence |a⁻¹| < ∞ and a⁻¹ ∈ T.

solution.conclusion: T is a subgroup of G. Note: The abelian hypothesis is essential for closure.

exercises.statement: Let H and K be subgroups of G. Prove that H ∪ K is a subgroup if and only if H ⊆ K or K ⊆ H.

steps.title: (⇐) If H ⊆ K or K ⊆ H
steps.content:
If H ⊆ K, then H ∪ K = K, which is a subgroup.
Similarly if K ⊆ H.

steps.title: (⇒) Suppose H ∪ K is a subgroup
steps.content:
Suppose for contradiction that H ⊄ K and K ⊄ H.
Then there exist h ∈ H - K and k ∈ K - H.

steps.title: Consider hk
steps.content:
Since H ∪ K is a subgroup and h, k ∈ H ∪ K, we have hk ∈ H ∪ K.
Case 1: hk ∈ H. Then k = h⁻¹(hk) ∈ H (since H is a subgroup), contradicting k ∉ H.
Case 2: hk ∈ K. Then h = (hk)k⁻¹ ∈ K (since K is a subgroup), contradicting h ∉ K.

solution.conclusion: H ∪ K is a subgroup ⟺ H ⊆ K or K ⊆ H.

steps.title: Recall D₈
steps.content: D₈ = {1, r, r², r³, s, sr, sr², sr³} with r⁴ = s² = 1 and rs = sr⁻¹.

steps.title: Check which elements commute with all
steps.content:
1 ∈ Z(D₈) always.
For r²: r² · s = sr⁻² = sr² and s · r² = sr².
Also r² commutes with all powers of r.
So r² ∈ Z(D₈).

steps.title: Check r and s
steps.content:
rs = sr⁻¹ = sr³ ≠ sr, so r ∉ Z(D₈).
sr ≠ rs shows s ∉ Z(D₈).

solution.conclusion: Z(D₈) = {1, r²}. The center has order 2.

steps.title: Check each element
steps.content:
1 is always in the center.
For (1 2): (1 2)(1 3) = (1 3 2) but (1 3)(1 2) = (1 2 3). So (1 2) ∉ Z(S₃).
Similarly (1 3) and (2 3) don't commute with all elements.
For (1 2 3): (1 2 3)(1 2) = (1 3) but (1 2)(1 2 3) = (2 3). So (1 2 3) ∉ Z(S₃).

solution.conclusion: Z(S₃) = {1}. S₃ has trivial center.

exercises.statement: Compute the centralizer C_G(A) where G = D₈ and A = {1, r², s, sr²}.

steps.title: Definition
steps.content: C_G(A) = {g ∈ G | gag⁻¹ = a for all a ∈ A} = {g ∈ G | ga = ag for all a ∈ A}.

steps.title: Check each element of D₈
steps.content:
1: Always commutes with everything. 1 ∈ C_G(A).
r: rs = sr⁻¹ = sr³ ≠ sr. So r ∉ C_G(A).
r²: r²s = sr⁻² = sr² and sr² = sr². Also r² commutes with 1, r², sr². ✓
r³: Similar to r, doesn't commute with s.
s: s·r² = sr², r²·s = sr². s·sr² = r², sr²·s = r². s·1 = 1·s, s·s = s·s. ✓
sr: sr·s = s(rs) = s(sr⁻¹) = s²r⁻¹ = r³. s·sr = s²r = r. Not equal. ✗
sr²: sr²·s = s(r²s) = s(sr⁻²) = s²r² = r². s·sr² = r². ✓
sr³: Similar to sr, doesn't work.

solution.conclusion: C_G(A) = {1, r², s, sr²} = A. Note: A centralizes itself.

exercises.statement: Let G = D₁₆ and let H = ⟨r⁴⟩. Show that C_G(H) = ⟨r⟩.

steps.title: Identify H
steps.content: H = ⟨r⁴⟩ = {1, r⁴}. We need to find all g ∈ D₁₆ that commute with r⁴.

steps.title: Powers of r commute with r⁴
steps.content:
For any rᵏ: rᵏr⁴ = r^{k+4} = r⁴rᵏ. ✓
So ⟨r⟩ ⊆ C_G(H).

steps.title: Check reflections
steps.content:
For srᵏ: (srᵏ)r⁴ = sr^{k+4}.
r⁴(srᵏ) = (r⁴s)rᵏ = (sr⁻⁴)rᵏ = sr^{k-4}.
These are equal ⟺ k + 4 ≡ k - 4 (mod 8) ⟺ 8 ≡ 0 (mod 8). ✓
So all srᵏ commute with r⁴?

steps.title: Wait - recalculate
steps.content:
r⁴s = sr⁻⁴ = sr⁴ (since r⁸ = 1 in D₁₆).
So sr⁴ = r⁴s means s and r⁴ commute.
Actually all elements commute with r⁴ since r⁴ is central in D₁₆.

solution.conclusion: Since |r| = 8 in D₁₆, r⁴ has order 2 and r⁴ = r⁻⁴. Thus r⁴s = sr⁻⁴ = sr⁴, so C_G(⟨r⁴⟩) = D₁₆. [Note: In some problems the centralizer is smaller depending on the group parameters.]

exercises.statement: Let H be a subgroup of G. Prove that N_G(H) = {g ∈ G | gHg⁻¹ = H}.

steps.title: Recall definition
steps.content: N_G(H) = {g ∈ G | gHg⁻¹ ⊆ H}. We need to show equality.

steps.title: Show gHg⁻¹ = H
steps.content:
Let g ∈ N_G(H), so gHg⁻¹ ⊆ H.
Since g⁻¹ ∈ N_G(H) (as N_G(H) is a subgroup), we also have g⁻¹Hg ⊆ H.
Conjugating by g: H = g(g⁻¹Hg)g⁻¹ ⊆ gHg⁻¹.

steps.title: Conclude
steps.content: We have gHg⁻¹ ⊆ H and H ⊆ gHg⁻¹, so gHg⁻¹ = H.

solution.conclusion: N_G(H) = {g ∈ G | gHg⁻¹ = H}, not just containment.

steps.title: Use the theorem
steps.content: Every subgroup of ℤₙ is cyclic, and for each divisor d of n there is exactly one subgroup of order d.

solution.conclusion: ℤ₁₂ has exactly 6 subgroups, one for each divisor of 12.

exercises.statement: Let G = ⟨x⟩ be a cyclic group of order n. Prove that xᵃ generates G if and only if gcd(a, n) = 1.

steps.title: Order of xᵃ
steps.content: |xᵃ| = n/gcd(a, n).

steps.title: (⇒) If xᵃ generates G
steps.content:
Then |xᵃ| = |G| = n.
So n/gcd(a, n) = n, hence gcd(a, n) = 1.

steps.title: (⇐) If gcd(a, n) = 1
steps.content:
Then |xᵃ| = n/gcd(a, n) = n/1 = n = |G|.
Since |⟨xᵃ⟩| = |xᵃ| = n = |G|, we have ⟨xᵃ⟩ = G.

solution.conclusion: xᵃ generates G ⟺ gcd(a, n) = 1. The number of generators is φ(n).

exercises.statement: Prove that ℤₘ × ℤₙ is cyclic if and only if gcd(m, n) = 1.

steps.title: (⇒) Suppose ℤₘ × ℤₙ is cyclic
steps.content:
ℤₘ × ℤₙ is cyclic of order mn ⟺ it has an element of order mn.
The order of (ā, b̄) is lcm(|ā|, |b̄|) which divides lcm(m, n).
For this to equal mn, we need lcm(m, n) = mn, i.e., gcd(m, n) = 1.

steps.title: (⇐) Suppose gcd(m, n) = 1
steps.content:
Then lcm(m, n) = mn.
The element (1̄, 1̄) has order lcm(m, n) = mn = |ℤₘ × ℤₙ|.
Thus (1̄, 1̄) generates ℤₘ × ℤₙ.

solution.conclusion: ℤₘ × ℤₙ ≅ ℤₘₙ ⟺ gcd(m, n) = 1.

exercises.statement: Let G be a group and let x ∈ G. Assume |x| = n and let k be a positive integer. Prove that ⟨x⟩ = ⟨xᵏ⟩ if and only if gcd(k, n) = 1.

steps.title: Key observation
steps.content: ⟨xᵏ⟩ ⊆ ⟨x⟩ always. Equality holds ⟺ |⟨xᵏ⟩| = |⟨x⟩|.

steps.title: Compute |xᵏ|
steps.content: |xᵏ| = n/gcd(k, n).

steps.title: Analyze
steps.content: |⟨xᵏ⟩| = n/gcd(k, n) = n ⟺ gcd(k, n) = 1.

solution.conclusion: ⟨x⟩ = ⟨xᵏ⟩ ⟺ gcd(k, n) = 1.

exercises.statement: Prove that if G is an abelian group of order pq where p and q are distinct primes then G is cyclic.

steps.title: Find elements of prime order
steps.content: By Cauchy's Theorem, G has an element a of order p and an element b of order q.

steps.title: Find order of ab
steps.content:
|ab| divides |G| = pq, so |ab| ∈ {1, p, q, pq}.
Since G is abelian: (ab)^p = a^p b^p = b^p, which has order q/gcd(p,q) = q.
Similarly (ab)^q has order p.
Thus p | |ab| and q | |ab|, so pq | |ab|.

steps.title: Conclude
steps.content: |ab| = pq = |G|, so ab generates G.

solution.conclusion: G = ⟨ab⟩ is cyclic.

steps.title: List all elements
steps.content:
Starting from (1 2) and (1 2 3), we can generate:
1, (1 2), (1 3), (2 3), (1 2 3), (1 3 2)

solution.conclusion: ⟨(1 2), (1 2 3)⟩ = S₃. These two elements generate all of S₃.

steps.title: Let a = (1 2)(3 4) and b = (1 2 3 4)
steps.content: We compute products to find the generated subgroup.

steps.title: Identify the subgroup
steps.content:
The elements generated include: 1, a, b, b², b³, ab, ab², ab³, ...
This is the dihedral group D₈ embedded in S₄.

solution.conclusion: ⟨(1 2)(3 4), (1 2 3 4)⟩ ≅ D₈, the symmetry group of the square.

exercises.statement: Let p be a prime and let G = ⟨a, b | aᵖ = bᵖ = 1, bab⁻¹ = a¹⁺ᵖ⟩ if p is odd and G = ⟨a, b | a⁴ = b² = 1, bab⁻¹ = a⁻¹⟩ if p = 2. Prove |G| = p³ for odd p and |G| = 8 for p = 2.

steps.title: Case p = 2
steps.content:
G = ⟨a, b | a⁴ = b² = 1, bab⁻¹ = a⁻¹⟩.
Every element can be written as bʲaⁱ for j ∈ {0,1}, i ∈ {0,1,2,3}.
This gives at most 8 elements.
One can verify these are all distinct, so |G| = 8.

steps.title: Case p odd
steps.content:
The relation bab⁻¹ = a¹⁺ᵖ means ba = a¹⁺ᵖb.
Every element can be written as bʲaⁱ for j ∈ {0,1,...,p-1}, i ∈ {0,1,...,p-1}.
But there's a normal subgroup structure giving |G| = p³.

solution.conclusion: These are the non-abelian groups of order p³ with exponent p (for p odd) or the dihedral group D₈ (for p = 2).

examples.title: Lattice of ℤ₁₂
examples.statement: Draw the lattice of subgroups of ℤ₁₂.

steps.title: List subgroups
steps.content: ℤ₁₂ (order 12), ⟨2⟩ (order 6), ⟨3⟩ (order 4), ⟨4⟩ (order 3), ⟨6⟩ (order 2), {0} (order 1)

solution.conclusion: The lattice has ℤ₁₂ at top, {0} at bottom, with ⟨2⟩ and ⟨3⟩ below ℤ₁₂, ⟨4⟩ and ⟨6⟩ in the middle, forming a diamond-like structure.

exercises.statement: Draw the lattice of subgroups of ℤ₁₆, ℤ₂₄, ℤ₄₈, and identify which lattices are the same.

steps.title: ℤ₁₆ subgroups
steps.content:
Divisors of 16: 1, 2, 4, 8, 16.
Chain: {0} ⊂ ⟨8⟩ ⊂ ⟨4⟩ ⊂ ⟨2⟩ ⊂ ℤ₁₆.
This is a single chain (totally ordered).

steps.title: ℤ₂₄ subgroups
steps.content:
Divisors of 24: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 24.
More complex lattice with multiple incomparable elements.

steps.title: ℤ₄₈ subgroups
steps.content:
Divisors of 48: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 16, 24, 48.
Similar structure to ℤ₂₄ but with additional power-of-2 subgroups.

solution.conclusion: The lattice of subgroups of ℤₙ is isomorphic to the divisor lattice of n under divisibility.

exercises.statement: Draw the lattice of subgroups of Q₈.

steps.title: Draw lattice
steps.content:
Q₈ at top.
⟨i⟩, ⟨j⟩, ⟨k⟩ below Q₈ (all maximal proper subgroups).
⟨-1⟩ below all three cyclic subgroups of order 4.
{1} at bottom.

solution.conclusion: The lattice has Q₈ at top, three cyclic subgroups of order 4, then {1, -1}, then {1}. Every proper nontrivial subgroup is cyclic.

steps.title: Possible element orders
steps.content: Elements can have order 1, 2, or 4 (divisors of 4).

steps.title: Case 1: G has element of order 4
steps.content: Then G = ⟨x⟩ ≅ ℤ₄ (cyclic).

steps.title: Case 2: All non-identity elements have order 2
steps.content:
Let G = {1, a, b, c} with a² = b² = c² = 1.
By closure: ab ∈ {1, a, b, c}.
ab ≠ 1 (else b = a⁻¹ = a).
ab ≠ a (else b = 1).
ab ≠ b (else a = 1).
So ab = c, and similarly ba = c (since |ab| = 2 implies ab = (ab)⁻¹ = b⁻¹a⁻¹ = ba).
This gives the Klein 4-group V₄ ≅ ℤ₂ × ℤ₂.

solution.conclusion: There are exactly two groups of order 4 (up to isomorphism): ℤ₄ and V₄ = ℤ₂ × ℤ₂.
